Derek is still right. Thunderf00t didn't actually prove Derek wrong, most of his experiments do not contradict the induction explanation. His first explicit contradictive argument (around 11.30) does not actually contradict (I left a long comment on that at Thunderf00t's video). Using distilled water does not contradict, since even ultra pure water is still a tiny bit conductive, which is actually already enough for the minuscule charges to be moved around to get electrostatic equilibrium (so higher conductivity does not even help). The most compelling effect (and most difficult to explain with induction) is that with the capillary at the end, but that still can be explained by induction. The part of the few centimeters long water column nearer to the charged plastic container gets more opposite charges attracted within that water column due to induction, ions of same charge are repelled to the other end, and then you get attraction for the near end.

More interesting: Some of Thunderf00t's experiments even actually disprove his own explanation:
Why is the continuous beam attracted and the droplets are not (17.40)? You have polar water in both cases, and if polarization is the cause, both should be attracted. So what's the difference between the continuous stream and the separated droplets? The continuous stream can conduct electricity along the stream; as soon as the water is separated into drops, it can't. Thus conductivity along the stream makes the difference between the effect working or not. Polarization is not affected by that. Electrostatic induction is. Thus electromagnetic induction is the main cause for water bending.
Funny enough, Thunderf00t even shows Derek's reply to Thunderf00t's previous video (0.45), where Derek uses that same argument, which Thunderf00t completely seems to ignore.

You're explanation that pure water can't be attracted to a charged object because it requires a very strong gradient is incorrect.  The water molecules will rotate in response to the field, lining up the opposite charge closest to the cup and same charge furthest.  The result is the surface of the water becomes polarized, with a significant separation and hence a large enough dipole moment that the gradient from the cup can affect it.  This induced polarization is well known, and water has a high polarizability due to the unbound polar molecules.

Maybe it's easiest to think in terms of macroscopic quantities, conductivity and dielectric constant, instead of the worrying about the complex motions of individual molecules or ions.
Water does have finite electrical conductivity, even "deionized" water. A conductor shields out electrostatic fields from its interior by carrying currents that set up surface charges, so there'll be an opposite charge layer on the near side of the water facing the cup, attracting it. Current doesn't actually need to flow all the way back to the faucet, though if it can, the net force can be increased. Only very small currents are needed to set up these net charge layers. Remember that the Coulomb is a very big unit of charge, and resulting force!!
Water is also strongly dielectric, with a dielectric constant of around 80 at low frequencies (below 100MHz or so). At the water surface a polarization charge layer appears, again attractive on the near surface and repulsive on the far surface, so with the field gradient across the entire droplet a net attractive force arises. (This indeed results from the polarization of the the individual molecules. In the interior of a droplet there is no net charge, negative and positive sides of the polarized molecules are next to each other, while on the surface there is an unbalanced charge layer of the outermost polarized molecules.)
So both mechanisms can operate. It is not obvious which may dominate in a given situation, it depends on how conductive the water is. Probably with tap water conductive shielding dominates, while with very highly deionized water, or other highly non-conductive and strongly dielectric liquids, the dielectric surface charge may dominate.

In our university was well-known task: "describe a behaviour of two not very small particles of a conductor, one of which is charged (for example positive) and the other is neutral" and the wrong answer was "no electric interaction" because in reality they will attract to each other. That is because in neutral particle there becomes charges splitting, and negative free charges come to that border of neutral particle, which is closer to the positive one. Positive free charges in neutral particle are concentrating near that border, which is opposite to the positive particle. So the distance of ++ interaction (repulsion) is greater then +- interaction (attraction) and the resulting force is attraction. I think this is the correct explanation of water jet deflection (and droplets also): the splitting of charges over the jetsection (or dropletsection).
Negative charges can not return to the water tap, as in this video, because such process violates the law of charge conservation (the crane becomes more and more negatively charged with new portions of water).

For the water attracting to the cup experiment, it is because of water's extremely polar nature. The way that I believe this works is that, through water's inter molecular forces via hydrogen bonding, large water "droplets" (relatively large they are still very very small) form together where, just like a magnet, each side is either positive or negatively charged, due to the dipoles of all the water molecules combining. So, with this droplet of water, the positive end would be attracted to the negative cup more than the negative side would be propelled because the positive side is closer; this is the same way the "positive" side of a magnet moves towards the positive side of another magnet, since the attraction of the magnet's negative side is stronger than the magnets repulsion. So, the water is drawn towards the cup. And i should mention that whether or not the cup is positive or negative doesnt matter

I teach physics and when I demonstrate static electricity by rubbing various objects with various fabrics to create positively charged and/or negatively charged objects that then attract or repel each other, I end by doing the following. I place an uncharged cylinder on a flat surface. Then I charge up one of my objects and place it close to the cylinder. The cylinder is always attracted to the charged object. This works for an aluminum can, which suggests that the charge shifts in the conducting aluminum. But a charged object also attracts a non conducting cylinder like a wooden spool or a cork.


I explain this as the charged object slightly polarizing the atoms nearest the charge and the charge that is repeled from the object is diminished compared to the opposite charge that is attracted to the charged on the object. In other words, the part of the polarized neutral object that is pushed away from the like charge on the charged object has less effect due to increased distance. The part of the polarized charge that is attracted to the charged object dominates because it is slightly closer and hence greater force. I hope that is correct. If not please do a video to explain how a neutral nonconducting object can be attracted to a second object that is highly charged. I claim this is also why a balloon that is charged by rubbing it on hair or cloth will stick to a neutral wall. There is a simulation on PhET that supports the explanation above.



So I guess this makes me wonder if the polarized charge is in fact contributing to the attraction in the demonstration of water attracted to a charged cup, even if it is not the sole reason.

Water droplets: negative ions do not go back into the faucet, its not PH (H+ and OH- migrating around) its the free electrons migrating around between the molecules.  That's how metal conducts electricity, the outer electrons are not tightly bound and randomly migrate around the substance, the easier they move, the better it conducts.  although water is a poor conductor of electricity, it does in fact conduct some, so there is a tiny percentage of electrons free to roam between the molecules. The first picture of the stream of water with the +/- lined up is wrong, they should be in random orientations, up, down, left, right, forward, back, and all kinds of diagonals in-between.  In the presence of the charged field of the cup, they will orient to the cup's field, and the attractive charge nearer the cup is pulled more strongly than the repulsive charge on the far side because the electric field strength is not linear but inverse square.  It's the same way that the attractive poles of magnets pull themselves together, despite the opposite side being repulsive, because the magnetic field is non-linear.

RE: teabag.... I'm not convinced that the levitation is due simply to buoyancy/convection. Yes, the buoyancy and convection is definitely what sets up the flow, and the density of the teabag ash needs to get low enough so that the fluid dynamic forces can overcome the force of gravity, but I think entrainment plays a large role here too. After all the tea bag (ash) isn't really encasing any hot air, and the bag/ash itself isn't any less dense than the surrounding air. Rather, the combustion of the teabag sets up a buoyant jet. This jet builds momentum traveling upwards, and air on the surface of the plate/table get's drawn towards the flame to replace the buoyant air thats rising away from it. Once the bag has mostly combusted and turned to ash it has a large enough surface area and low enough weight that the rising buoyant jet  can entrain it in the flow. This flow will persist even for a short while after the fire has gone out due to momentum of the buoyant jet. So essentially the drag force on the tea-bag eventually overcomes the force of gravity once the teabag has lost enough mass that the force of gravity on the bag/ash becomes less than the drag force entraining it in the buoyant jet.

The explanation of the deflection of a stream of falling liquid is not completely correct.  It is not necessary for the liquid to have ions.  As another commenter mentioned, even extremely pure water, having only 10^-14 M/L of hydronium and hydroxide ions is deflected.  Even more telling is that a stream of a completely nonpolar liquid, such as benzene or carbon tetrachloride, in which ionic substances do not dissolve, is also deflected, albeit much less than water.  The correct answer is that a charge on the liquid stream is induced by the presence of the charged cup or comb.

your cane thing is slightly off. if you support the cane off center. If you move your fingers somewhat fast the side with the most weight on your finger, will move the cane and produce sufficient momemtum to continue on and fall off the other side. If however you do it real fast. the inertia out does the friction altogether and the cane will fall toward the heavier side. So in effect if the object is held off center or an object such as a broom is used then you can control which way the cane falls by the speed of your bringing your hands together. This of course will not work with a stick that is equally weighed and held at the far ends to start. with a little practice you can make it fall which ever way you wish. and use it as a teaching tool for inertia, momentum, and friction.

PLEASE READ! The negatively charged and the stream of water from the faucet would still work with distilled water, too. What would happen is that the electrons on the cup would repel the negative oxygen end and attract the positive hydrogen end. As the water falls, the oxygen end is pushed away, therefore just that much further away from the cup, and the hydrogen end is pulled toward the cup, therefore closer to the cup. This interaction is due to Coulomb's Law. Because of Coulomb's Law, the hydrogen end is more strongly pulled toward the cup than the oxygen end is pushed away. This results in a net overall force toward the cup. Just so, the cup experiences the same net force toward the stream of water.

This is theoretically correct. Whether or not this effect is enough to see an appreciable deflection in the stream of water is another question altogether. It may be due to ions as well. The combined effect may be enough.

Awesome video, but I do have one complaint. I believe that your explanation for the deflection of water is misleading. It's certainly true that a charged cup will repel one kind of ion and attract the other, leading to a net attractive force, but this is not necessary for the attraction to occur. Even if the water were completely deionized, the cup's surface charges (say they're negative) will repel the electron clouds in the water molecules and attract the atomic nuclei, polarizing the water molecules. This polarization will occur until all of the forces are in equilibrium , but the net effect is still an uneven charge distribution that will be attracted to the cup. It doesn't matter whether the water molecules were polar before, and even though this induced dipole is much greater than the preexisting one,the bottom line is that this phenomenon will be observed regardless of the molecules' polarity or the presence of ions in solution.

I still don't see how the Van der Waals forces in the water alone are insufficient to cause the bending of the water. The electrical force will rotate the polar molecules so that the protons face toward the negative electric field, while the electrons face away from it. You are saying that the forces on the molecules would then cancel out and be equal but opposite, however, this is still not true.

The protons are closer to the negative field, and the electrons are farther away from it. The attractive force on the protons will now be greater than the repulsive force on the electrons affecting a net attractive force on the molecule.

In other words, because the subatomic particles are now at different distances away from the electric field, there will be a force disparity thus causing a net acceleration toward the field.

This is a contradiction since we know that the stick remain balanced in the final position where the fingers have met. Hence our assumption was wrong. HEY DEREK, (PLEASE READ THIS COMMENT!)
I am concerned with your response for water being attracted to a cup. You said that in water there are sometimes some ions which are attracted to the cup. This implies that deionised water which doesn't have any ions should not be attracted to the cup but that is not true in fact. Deionised water still is attracted to the cup. My explanation for this however is as follows:
The water molecules electron cloud is uniform to start with when it is not acted upon by an external charge. As we also know, water molecules are neutral in charge. But when a charged cup for example approaches a molecule of water, it disturbs its electron cloud and makes the water molecule more negative on one side but the overall charge of the water molecule is still zero. Let's assume that the electron cloud distribution pattern on the water molecule is spherical in shape and what happens when the charged cup approaches the molecule is that it makes the water's electron cloud distribution change to a pear like shape rather than a spherical shape which makes the water molecule more positive on one side and more negative on the other side.
Thanks!

Your explanation on the faucet is slightly incorrect. OH- and H+ (H3O+) are not the major sources of ions.

Kw = [OH][H]
Kw at 25C = 1 * 10-14
That's an extremely small amount of ions.

Furthermore, the rate of spontaneous ionization is about one ionization per 10 hours and the rate of recombination is 1 picosecond.

The amount of OH- and H+ (H3O+) in pure water, therefore, is effectively negligible.

Many substances are theoretically conductive, but so little that it's essentially 0. The electrical conductivity of ultrapure water due to OH- and H3O+ is 5.5E-6 S/m. For comparison, sea water--that is, water with ample solutes--is 5 S/m. The electrical conductivity is relevant because the movement of ions is an electric current.

Source: Various articles on the properties of water from wikipedia.

Actually, for the water expt., we can totally explain it as the dipole moment of water. 
Its true that water contains both positive charge and negative charges, but notice that the shape of water isnt symmetrical, it has a V shape which creates the permanent dipole moment with one end is positive (the end with 2 H) and the other end is negative (the O). When you bring the rod with the negv.charge for example, the posi. pole will rearrange toward the negv.
The IMPORTANT part here is the distance between the posi charge and the negv charge is closer than the distance between the negv of the water and the negv charge on the rod. This makes the attraction stronger than the repulsion thus the water deflect toward the rod. 

So pure water will be deflected by the charge as well. It's not necessary for the water to contain other ions to get deflected!

The explanation for the cane trick is incomplete. In the first video you showed how you get both your fingers on the center of mass by sliding them from the ends, and the cane remained on your two fingers. But it did not remain there when you simply put your fingers under the center of mass, and that, I believe, is the more interesting question.
Thing is, by simply putting your fingers under the center of mass, you've got your wobbly skin in between the solid cane and your solid bones. The skin being wobbly and mushy, it will make the cane lean a bit to the right or to the left, thereby shifting the center of mass and making the cane fall. BUT, if you slide your fingers on the cane towards the center, the friction on both fingers will cause your skin to slowly "roll" on your bones and get into a state of tension, with a tendency to roll back into the initial position. This way, then you reach the center of mass, you've got the skin on bot your fingers pulling inwards, trying to get back in it's natural position, making it much more difficult for the cane to lean left or right and shift it's center of mass. this would be much easier for me to explain with a couple of drawings, but I'm too lazy to upload them.

I think he has a mistake about the attraction of liquids in a cup, when he says "even non-polar substances with dissolve ions in them"

because it is highly unlikely that a non-polar liquid can dissolve an "ion"... example: consider liquid hexane and table salt... hexane is non-polar and since it is non-polar, it doesn't have enough energy/charge to break/separate the bond between Na ion and Cl ion, thus, rendering the NaCl undissolved in hexane (i.e. "ions" will not dissolve in non-polar solvents)...

consequently, polar molecules like water can easily dissolve "ions"... so in a way, regardless whether we consider the polar nature of water, or its ability to generate its own ions (H+ and OH-) or its ability to dissolve other ions, or all of those; the cup experiment will directly leads to the explanation: "it is due to the polar nature of water"...

Surely the reason why the phone won't spin in that axis has to do with aerodynamics instead... Both the act of throwing it into the air and the force of gravity pulling it down are working on the phone in a vertical plane, so the phone will always try to get itself to be as aerodynamic as possible in that up-down plane. The large surface area of the front of the phone is going to act almost like a sail, causing relatively large air resistance that will turn the phone to its more aerodynamic side at the slightest opportunity.

I agree that the dissolved ions play a major role; however, those dissolved ions are covered by a somewhat spherical hydration shell which negates the ion charge to a certain degree and orients the water molecules accordingly. Moreover, the equilibrium of the equilibrium reaction, H2O<--->H3O+ and OH-, is highly on the side of water H2O. The concentration of H3O+ ions in water is around ~10^(-7) mole per liter by ~0°C to ~30°C. That gives ~6.022*10^16 hydronium cations per liter of water. A liter of water has 55.5 mole which gives us a 1/555,000,000 ratio of H20 to H30+.

Well, I have a different explanation for 1 and 3. Here it goes.

1) Consider Derek and the stick as the system. There are three things in the system whose motion is to be described, they are, the left and the right hands and the stick. The initial momentum of the system of elements is zero. Everything is at rest initially. Since no external forces act on the system, momentum is conserved. This implies, the final momentum of the system of elements is zero. At the final configuration, the momentum of the left and the right hands is zero because they stop at the point where they meet. This leaves us with the stick, whose momentum has to be zero. The stick may possess both translational momentum and rotational momentum. Since the two momenta cannot be added( due to the absence of dimensional homogeneity ), both should equal to zero. Coming to rotational momentum or angular momentum, which is zero, there is no flipping or rotational motion. Since it continues to stay in that configuration( constant angular velocity that is equal to zero ), we say that the net torque about the pivot( Derek's fingers ) is zero. By definition, the net torque about the center of mass of an isolated element is always zero and in this case, the system as mentioned above is isolated. This implies that the center of mass of the stick rests on Derek's fingers.

3) The electric field created by the charged insulating cup is not uniform. To be clear, take a cylindrical cup( almost identical to the one in the video ) with its bottom surface missing and let it have a uniform surface charge density. On calculating the electric field intensity at any point in space( using Gauss's law for this special symmetric situation ), one will observe that the electric field intensity follows an inverse 'r' relationship where 'r' is the distance from the central axis of the cylinder. As a consequence, the net force on the water molecule will not be zero. The net force on the molecule causes it to deflect from its initial flow direction. So, in this case even pure water deflects. The cane explanation is not exactly right, the finger that is closest to the center of gravity isn't bearing more of the canes weight. The center of gravity (cg) is were the weight is expressed. Using statics the sum of all the y components and the sum of the moments about a certain point must equal zero. The sum of all the y components cannot be solved without the sum of the moments, there are two unknowns and two equations. Thus, the solution to the cane problem is solved with the moments about a certain point. A moment is force x moment arm or length from the cg. At any point the moment arm is a known factor thus the moments about the cg must be equal to maintain equilibrium. The finger that is closest to the cg has to have more force on it because the moment arm is shorter (force x moment). The more force the more friction and thus the finger furthest away from the cg will slide. ~Cheers, love your videos!

I'm fairly sure the water one is a different explanation. It's due to polarity but the polarity is induced by the static electricity. this applies to any fluid regardless of it's original polarity. When rubbed the cup gains electrons from the static interaction and so becomes negatively charged and repels the electrons of the water molecules and forms a positive side of the molecule closer to the negative cup and the opposites attract. This is because the cup is not a uniform electric field. There is a charged centre and the field dissipates further and further away. the strength of the field is proportional to the radius^2 so the attractive force on the positive pole is greater than the repulsive force on the negative pole of the water molecule.

Not so sure about the axis explanation. It seems true for objects with kind of a constant density in all of it. But a phone has no constant density. To me, together with that explanation, I would say that the longest and shortest axis rotations "work" because in the first one (opposite to the latter), if you look from the point of view of the side of the rotation (like it is rotating towards you), everything is packed, "compressed", so, given enough momentum, it will work kind of a gyroscope. Much like a wheel.

In the shortest axis version, the components of the phone are close to the axis of rotation, so this movement, given enough momentum, will make it hard for deviations in the distribution of mass (or density) to affect lateral movement.

However, the "medium axis" movement has the "worst" of both cases, with components being away from the axis of rotation and, probably, being distributed in a non "constant density" way, so any irregular distribution of mass will have an effect in its lateral movement.

Again, much like a wheel, if you add some weight to the side of a rim, it will not rotate properly, and that's why they calibrate for that when you change your tyres. Even small weights (in the scale of grams) can do much difference.

But that's just my two cents.

The cane balancing explanation seems incomplete. When you start from a balanced, stable position, it's easier to maintain that balanced state (especially considering you maintain a two-point contact throughout). We adjust our hands and muscles to maintain that balance, instinctively accounting for friction as well as relative speed and position of each hand.

When you have to determine the center of mass by sight and apply pressure at that point directly from the start, you're far more likely to fail. You don't have a good sense of the center of mass from feel and you have far less stability to work with (one point rather than two).
